titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William S. Burroughs Papers MSS.625
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy and Lauren Stark

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-05-23 17:30:54 UTC.

change.item: Finding aid updated by Lauren Stark to reflect processing of collection

physdesc.extent: in 52 manuscript boxes, 1 cassette box, 1 flat file folder, 2 shared card boxes, and 4 folders in 2 shared flat boxes

did.abstract: William S. Burroughs (1914-1997) was an American writer and visual artist primarily associated with postmodernism and the Beat Generation subculture. He wrote 18 novels and novellas, six collections of short stories, four collections of essays, and five books have been published of his interviews and correspondences. Burroughs also collaborated on projects and recordings with numerous performers and musicians, made many appearances in films, and created and exhibited thousands of visual artworks, including his celebrated "Shotgun Art." Burroughs' semiautobiographical writing often addressed themes of substance use, homosexuality, mysticism, and death, and frequently employed experimental prose and unreliable narrators. The William S. Burroughs Papers (bulk 1981-1997) consist of materials documenting Burroughs' personal and professional life as a novelist and short story writer. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence and manuscripts in various stages of completion. Notable correspondents include Paul Bowles, Lucien Carr, Gregory Corso, Allen Ginsberg, Ted Morgan, David Ohle, and Patti Smith. Works documented in this collection include The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets (a musical fable created with Tom Waits and Robert Wilson, 1989), My Education: A Book of Dreams (1995), the editorial selection The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959 (1993), as well as shorter works, including "Death Fiend Guerrillas", Ghost of Chance, "The Johnson Family", and Tornado Alley. The materials document not only Burroughs' artistic process, but also the larger context of postmodern literature and the Beat Generation subculture.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials are mostly in English. A few letters, articles, and reviews are in French, Spanish, German, and Italian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William S. Burroughs Papers (bulk 1981-1997) consist of materials documenting Burroughs' personal and professional life as a novelist and short story writer. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence and manuscripts in various stages of completion. Notable correspondents include Paul Bowles, Lucien Carr, Gregory Corso, Allen Ginsberg, Ted Morgan, David Ohle, and Patti Smith. Works documented in this collection include The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets (a musical fable created with Tom Waits and Robert Wilson, 1989), My Education: A Book of Dreams (1995), the editorial selection The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959 (1993), as well as shorter works, including "Death Fiend Guerrillas", Ghost of Chance, "The Johnson Family", and Tornado Alley. However, there is not a significant amount of material for Burroughs' more well-known works, such as Naked Lunch and other novels. The materials document not only Burroughs' artistic process, but also the larger context of postmodern literature and the Beat Generation subculture. Many of the folders are decorated, but materials documenting Burroughs' career as a visual artist are not a significant part of this collection. Burroughs' frequent use of the themes of substance use, homosexuality, and death, as well as his general interests in firearms, animals, and the occult, are well documented in the collection through his subject files. Additional autobiographical material is provided by a few personal items, including psychiatric evaluations, a series of letters with his doctors, photographs, and an employee's lawsuit regarding unpaid wages. Additional collaborative work is evident through event posters and flyers, materials related to his participation in a video by the band U2, and materials related to Literary Outlaw: The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs by Ted Morgan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged into six series, one of which has been further arranged into subseries. The series and subseries arrangement is as follows:
Subseries III.A. The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullet
Subseries III.B. Everything Lost: The Latin American Notebook of William S. Burroughs
Subseries III.C. The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959
Subseries III.D. My Education: A Book of Dreams
Subseries III.F. Short Stories and Novellas
Subseries III.G. Unpublished and Unrealized Projects
All series and subseries are arranged alphabetically.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: One letter and envelope from Allen Ginsberg to William S. Burroughs with evidence of mold were photocopied, and the originals discarded. A tablecloth, scarf, and personal items of James Grauerholz were removed and returned to the donor.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William S. Burroughs (1914-1997) was an American writer and visual artist primarily associated with postmodernism and the Beat Generation subculture. He wrote 18 novels and novellas, six collections of short stories, four collections of essays, and five books have been published of his interviews and correspondences. Burroughs also collaborated on projects and recordings with numerous performers and musicians, made many appearances in films, and created and exhibited thousands of visual artworks, including his celebrated "Shotgun Art." Burroughs' semiautobiographical writing often addressed themes of substance use, homosexuality, mysticism, and death, and frequently employed experimental prose and unreliable narrators.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from James Grauerholz via The Wylie Agency in June 2021, and transferred to NYU Special Collections in December 2022. The accession number associated with this purchase is 2023.004.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Fales Library and Special Collections, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; William S. Burroughs Papers; MSS 625; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes, retaining original folders and order. Boxes were condensed or expanded in order to properly house materials; as a result, box and folder numbers do not completely correspond with the original inventory prepared by the seller. A crosswalk of original to NYU box numbers is available in the collection's accession record.
Audio cassettes were also physically separated from their original locations to be housed together in an appropriate-sized box.

At the time of processing in 2025, the collection was arranged and described into series. Materials were placed into acid-free legal boxes and folders, and oversized materials were rehoused in appropriately sized boxes. Items were removed from non-archival sleeves. Duplicate publications and documents, publications widely available online or in NYU's catalog holdings, and documents with sensitive personal information were removed.

In most cases, painted file folders were retained with their original contents, but rehoused in paper sleeves behind these items. In instances where the original contents were deaccessioned, painted file folders were moved to Series IV.

21 floppy disks were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged in Forensic Toolkit. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional archival collections on William Burroughs are held at the Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature at the New York Public Library, Columbia University's Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Ohio State University's Rare Books and Manuscript Library, and Emory University Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials related to Burroughs' personal life. Materials, which reflect his day to day life, include psychiatric evaluations, correspondence with doctors, a lawsuit from a former employee for unpaid wages, a bill for firearms, photographs, itineraries, a Scientology routine, and a card for a narcotics dependence program.

unittitle.emph: Bradley H. Koehler v. William Burroughs Communications

did.unittitle: Psychiatric Evaluations and Correspondence with Doctors

physdesc.extent: in 25 manuscript boxes, 1 cassette box, 1 oversize folder, and 2 folders in 2 shared flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of letters, writing, press, and in some cases, artwork, with various correspondents, both personal and professional. Some files contain more publicity and less direct correspondence, as with Jean-Michel Basquiat, whose file includes an exhibition annoucement, and Andy Warhol, whose file includes his memorial program. Additionally, there is general correspondence, consisting of fan mail, requests for interviews, and publisher requests for feedback and reviews. These materials illustrate Burroughs' interest in maintaining numerous personal relationshsips and connections to his readers.

did.unittitle: American Academy of Arts and Letters
American Federation of Television and Radio Artists
Anderson, Heidi -- Re: David Budd's Memorial
De Chadenèdes, John, David, and Audrey
Partouche, Marc, Rosine Buhler, et al. -- Collaborative Art Book

physdesc.extent: in 23 manuscript boxes, 1 cassette box, and 1 folder in 1 shared flat box

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically into seven subseries and alphanumerically within each one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists mostly of manuscript pages and drafts of Burroughs' writing, both published and unpublished. Publications include The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets, My Education: A Book of Dreams (1995), and The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959 (1993), as well as shorter works, including "Death Fiend Guerrillas", Ghost of Chance, "The Johnson Family", and Tornado Alley. Unpublished works consist of materials used for readings and events, daily journals, and many untitled manuscripts. Although many of the published works in the collection might not be as well known as some of Burroughs' other works, they all illustrate his signature semiautobiographical style (autobiographical in some cases here) and his lengthy revision process.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.A. The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets

physdesc.extent: in 5 manuscript boxes and 1 cassette box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials related to The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets (first performed in 1990), an opera based on a German folktale, co-created by the theater director Robert Wilson, musician Tom Waits, and Burroughs. Materials include correspondence between the collaborators, correspondence with various theaters, drafts and manuscripts of the text, musical compositions, research materials, notes, German translations, theater programs, and audio recordings of rehearsals and songs.

did.unittitle: Background Material -- Der Freischutz -- Folk Legend Synopsis and Opera Script
Scene Notes -- James Grauerholz, Greg, Robert Wilson, and Tom Waits
Text and Speech Lists and Counts
Revisions with Songs -- German and English
English and German Translations -- Possibly Final Versions
Video Reviews -- Read-Along English Text and Notes
Subseries III.B. Everything Lost: The Latin American Notebook of William S. Burroughs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to Everything Lost: The Latin American Notebook of William S. Burroughs (2007), Burroughs' reflections of his four years in Latin America, specifically Mexico City, Ecuador, Colombia, and Peru. Materials include photocopies of the first proof and transcript.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.C. The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to The Letters of William S. Burroughs, Vol. 1: 1945-1959 (1993), a collection of Burroughs' correspondence edited and introduced by Oliver Harris. Materials consist of various drafts of the letters, footnotes, acknowledgements, and the introduction, in both analog and digital formats. Also included are editor's notes and questions, word counts, reviews, and correspondence with publishers.

did.unittitle: Second Draft with Partial Revisions and Notes
Subseries III.D. My Education: A Book of Dreams

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries My Education: A Book of Dreams consists of materials related to this collection of Burroughs' dreams, published as a novel/memoir in 1995. Materials include various drafts, in both analog and digital formats, notes, correspondence with publishers, inserts and additions, reviews and press, and cover art.

did.unittitle: Page Proofs -- Cover Flap and Frontispiece

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 cassette box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials related to Burroughs' novels, some of which are his most well-known, such as Naked Lunch and Queer. Materials include the audio abridgment transcript of Queer; audio recordings and transcripts for the audiobook version of Junkie: Confessions of an Unredeemed Drug Addict, or Junky; excerpt typescripts for Naked Lunch and Nova Express; and drafts and cover art for The Place of Dead Roads, Port of Saints, and The Western Lands.

did.unittitle: Cities of the Red Night -- Protagonist Description and Cover Proof for Reissue

unittitle.emph: Junkie: Confessions of an Unredeemed Drug Addict, or Junky

did.unittitle: Junky: The Definitive Text of "Junk" -- Correspondence and Notes

Screenplay by Terry Southern -- First Draft
"The Sky Is Thin as Paper Here" -- Reading Copy
Screenplay by David Ohle -- Manuscript and Correspondence
Subseries III.F. Short Stories, Novellas, Essays, and Other Published Material

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 folder in 1 shared flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries focuses on Burroughs' shorter published works, including novellas, short stories, essays and essay collections, and contributions to other authors' publications. Materials consist of manuscript drafts (both analog and digital) and notes for "Death Fiend Guerrillas", The Cat Inside, Ghost of Chance, "The Johnson Family," and Tornado Alley. Also included are drafts and correspondence with authors and publishers for introductions, prefaces, and contributions for other publications, such as Anne Waldman's The Beat Book (1996).

Subseries III.G. Unpublished and Unrealized Projects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of Burroughs' unpublished work. Materials includes handwritten notes on index cards, journal and dream entries (mostly labeled as "Day to Day"), unpublished manuscripts (mostly typescripts but some handwritten), and manuscripts and correspondence related to unrealized projects, such as a contribution to "The New Gothic," in both analog and digital formats. Many of these materials were used by Burroughs for public readings and other events and include reworkings of possibly published material.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Since the "Day to Day" files appeared to have an established chronological arrangement, they were not further arranged by the archivist.

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes and 1 folder in 1 shared flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists mainly of painted file folders, a few sketches, and targets from a firing range. Also included are Burroughs' artist CV and exhibition announcements, catalogs, and a poster. In most cases, painted file folders were retained with their original contents. In instances where the original contents were deaccessioned, painted file folders were moved to this series.

did.unittitle: Early Artwork -- Self-Portrait and Mayan Drawings -- Photocopies
"Entrance to Museum of Extinct Species" -- File Folder Painting
"What Happened on the Mary Celeste?" -- Color Printout

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes and 2 folders in 2 shared flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mostly consists of materials related to Burroughs' participation in public events, such as readings and lectures. Materials include event announcements (posters, flyers, and advertisements), correspondence, clippings and other press, and production schedules. Also included are materials related to The Final Academy, a four-day multimedia festival in England organized by Genesis P-Orridge and others in 1982. Materials include programs, schedules, tickets, and reviews. This series also contains materials related to Ted Morgan's biography of Burroughs, Literary Outlaw: The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs (1988); materials such as correspondence, notes, FOIA files from the FBI, archival files from Time, and transcripts of interviews with Burroughs are included.

did.unittitle: Literary Outlaw: The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs by Ted Morgan
Research Material from the CIA, FBI, and Time

physdesc.extent: in 4 manuscript boxes and 1 folder in 1 shared flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes printed material (articles, clippings, journals, and catalogs) on various topics of interest to Burroughs. Many of these topics, such as firearms, animals, drugs, and the occult, were frequent subjects of his writing. Additional subjects covered include the Illuminates of Thanateros and UFOs. Also included is writing by other authors (such as David Ohle and Spencer Kansa).

unittitle.emph: Anarchy: A Journal of Desire Armed
